data.title: Washington Nationals News, Schedule, Stats and Roster
data.meta_description: Latest Washington Nationals news, schedule, stats, depth chart, roster, injuries, transactions and more from USA TODAY Sports.

Ruiz started just one of the past three games and will have Thursday's scheduled off day to aid in his recovery from the ailment. The 25-year-old posted a .717 OPS with 18 homers in 136 games last season, but he has a .194/.265/.290 slash line through 34 plate appearances this season.

ðŸ¤”

Despite blowing a four-run lead Monday against the Diamondbacks, the right-hander is one of the top relievers on the market with 28 saves and a 3.48 ERA through 46 appearances this year. Finnegan will have his final year of arbitration eligibility in 2025, and the Nationals are trying to take advantage of the sellers' market at the deadline.

ðŸ¤”

Thomas' eight homers and .728 OPS through 76 games this season is a bit underwhelming after he clubbed 28 homers with a .783 OPS last year. However, the outfielder has already set a career high with 28 stolen bases, and he has a .299/.420/.373 slash line in his past 18 contests. The Royals haven't been getting consistent offensive production from their outfielders this season, so Kansas City would be a logical landing spot for Thomas.

ðŸ¤”

The right-handed journeyman posted a 3.60 ERA in 54 outings for the Reds in 2023 and has continued to pitch well for the Nationals this year with a 3.30 ERA, 1.30 WHIP and 53:17 K:BB over 60 innings. Law won't significantly move the needle for contending teams, but his work in middle relief could still provide a boost to an undermanned bullpen.

ðŸ¤”

Winker hasn't played an inning in the outfield this month and Atlanta has a full-time designated hitter already in Marcell Ozuna. However, if the club is comfortable with Winker playing the field, it surely would have interest in his bat. The 30-year-old is slashing .260/.374/.432 in a bounce-back season, and the impending free agent is making just $2 million on a one-year pact.

ðŸ¤”

Wood will reportedly be called up Monday, and the expectation is that he will see most of his action in left field while Jesse Winker serves as the designated hitter, which would leave Rosario without a path to regular at-bats. Rosario looked like he might be turning a corner in May when he put up an .839 OPS, but his production has fallen off a cliff again in June with a .188/.197/.250 line.

ðŸ¤”

The right-hander appeared to enter 2024 with a chance to see some saves, but Kyle Finnegan has locked down the closer role with the best year of his career. Harvey has labored of late with four walks and four earned runs allowed over his past two outings, but he had a 2.68 ERA through 34 appearances prior to the recent struggles. The 29-year-old will enter his final year of arbitration eligibility in 2025 before hitting free agency.

ðŸ¤”

Floro signed with Washington on a one-year, $2.25 million contract in December, and his 2.15 ERA, 1.06 WHIP and 28:10 K:BB through 39 outings should make him a popular trade target this summer. The 33-year-old tallied 32 saves from 2021 to 2023, but is without a save so far this season and is unlikely to be in the ninth-inning mix if traded.

ðŸ¤”

The veteran left-hander seemed to be a sure bet to be jettisoned from Washington's rotation when Gray began his rehab assignment in early June, but Corbin has responded by allowing just five runs with a 16:5 K:BB over 17.1 frames in his past three starts. The 34-year-old's 5.46 ERA is still second worst in the majors among 72 qualified starting pitchers, but the recent improvement could grant him a longer leash in the short term, with the Nationals likely hoping to convert that success into a trade.

ðŸ¤”

Thomas had a .268/.315/.468 slash line with 28 homers and 20 steals last season, but he's hitting just .223 through 38 games in 2024. However, the 28-year-old missed most of May with a knee sprain, and he has an .806 OPS in 16 contests since he returned from the injured list. Thomas is under contract through the 2025 campaign, so it's a natural time for Washington to consider its trade options with a year and a half left under club control. The club will also need to find room in the outfield for top prospects like James Wood, who is currently sidelined by a hamstring injury, and Dylan Crews in the near future.

ðŸ¤”

The right-hander is enjoying a career year in 2024 with 18 saves and a 1.65 ERA, 0.84 WHIP and 29:10 K:BB across 27.1 innings, so it would make sense for Washington to try and sell high given his career 3.33 ERA. Finnegan is making $5.1 million this season in his penultimate year of arbitration eligibility, so it's a logical window to maximize his trade value since he's still under contract for a year and a half.

ðŸ¤”

The veteran outfielder joined Washington as a non-roster invitee in February, and he's enjoyed a rebound campaign with six homers, 11 steals and a .261/.375/.396 slash line in 64 games. Flipping him at the trade deadline appeared to be the best-case scenario for the Nationals when signing him, and Winker has managed to rebuild his trade value after a couple down seasons.

ðŸ¤”

The veteran right-hander landed on the injured list last week, but prior to that he was one of the better stories of the first half of the season. Williams posted a 5.55 ERA in 30 starts for Washington last year, but in 2024 he has a 2.22 ERA, 1.08 WHIP and 47:16 K:BB across 56.2 innings. The 32-year-old is set to become a free agent after the season and could be a strong trade rental for contending teams, assuming he doesn't spend too long on the shelf.

ðŸ¤”

Washington hopes Adams can get back on track offensively at Triple-A, as his .215/.281/.354 slash line through 25 games this season is a sharp drop from his .807 OPS in 2023. Drew Millas is up with the Nationals as the backup catcher to Keibert Ruiz, but Adams could rejoin the big club before long if he can build on his hot start with Rochester, as he went 8-for-17 with three homers in his first four contests.

ðŸ¤”

Opposing batters hit .417 against the right-hander's slider last season, so he tweaked his arsenal during the offseason. Finnegan is throwing the sweeper at the same rate of 5.2 percent, so it's a small sample size of just 13 pitches. The 32-year-old has enjoyed a strong start to the campaign with a 1.65 ERA, 0.86 WHIP and 16:8 K:BB across 16.1 innings, and he's likely to be a popular trade target this summer if the Nationals aren't in playoff contention.

â€Œ

â€Œ

â€Œ

Williams has thrown his four-seam fastball 36.4 percent of the time through seven starts in 2024, which is down from 43.2 percent last season and is the lowest of his big-league career, per Andrew Golden of The Washington Post.

ðŸ¤”

The four-seamer is still his primary offering, but he also has four other pitches that feature rates between 12 and 19 percent. The biggest difference is in his sweeper usage, a pitch Williams introduced in 2023 but threw just 73 times in 30 starts. He's using it at a 17.9 percent clip this season and is giving up a .167 batting average on it. The overall shift in his arsenal was necessary, as the right-hander's average fastball velocity now sits under 90 mph, and the change has brought immediate results with a 1.96 ERA, 1.06 WHIP and 30:12 K:BB over 36.2 frames in 2024.

ðŸ¤”

Rainey spent most of last season rehabbing from Tommy John surgery, and his fastball velocity in 2024 is down more than three ticks from his career average. The right-hander has given up 12 earned runs with an 8:11 K:BB over 12 innings this season and appeared to be in danger of losing his roster spot with Robert Garcia returning from the injured list Tuesday; however, the Nationals aren't yet ready to expose Rainey to waivers, as he is out of minor-league options. The 31-year-old may need to turn a corner soon if he's to retain his place in the bullpen much longer.

ðŸ¤”

No major trades are likely to happen anytime soon, especially for Thomas given the injury, but the outfielder could end up on the block again this summer after the Nationals elected to hold onto him last year. The 28-year-old was off to a poor start prior to the injury with a .184/.250/.253 through 22 games, but he's still likely to be a popular trade candidate this summer, assuming he's healthy, after he posted a .783 OPS last season.

ðŸ¤”

Washington called up infielder Trey Lipscomb in a corresponding move, as the club opted not to bolster their outfield depth. Senzel's only action in the field has come at third base this season, but he primarily played the outfield during his five seasons in Cincinnati.

ðŸ¤”

Ruiz started just one of the past three games and will have Thursday's scheduled off day to aid in his recovery from the ailment. The 25-year-old posted a .717 OPS with 18 homers in 136 games last season, but he has a .194/.265/.290 slash line through 34 plate appearances this season.

Despite blowing a four-run lead Monday against the Diamondbacks, the right-hander is one of the top relievers on the market with 28 saves and a 3.48 ERA through 46 appearances this year. Finnegan will have his final year of arbitration eligibility in 2025, and the Nationals are trying to take advantage of the sellers' market at the deadline.

ðŸ¤”

St. Louis is seeking relief help and as an impending free agent, Floro is a likely candidate to be dealt. The veteran reliever has posted a 2.06 ERA and 40:13 K:BB across 52.1 innings this season out of the Washington bullpen.

ðŸ¤”

Thomas' eight homers and .728 OPS through 76 games this season is a bit underwhelming after he clubbed 28 homers with a .783 OPS last year. However, the outfielder has already set a career high with 28 stolen bases, and he has a .299/.420/.373 slash line in his past 18 contests. The Royals haven't been getting consistent offensive production from their outfielders this season, so Kansas City would be a logical landing spot for Thomas.

ðŸ¤”

The right-handed journeyman posted a 3.60 ERA in 54 outings for the Reds in 2023 and has continued to pitch well for the Nationals this year with a 3.30 ERA, 1.30 WHIP and 53:17 K:BB over 60 innings. Law won't significantly move the needle for contending teams, but his work in middle relief could still provide a boost to an undermanned bullpen.

ðŸ¤”

Winker hasn't played an inning in the outfield this month and Atlanta has a full-time designated hitter already in Marcell Ozuna. However, if the club is comfortable with Winker playing the field, it surely would have interest in his bat. The 30-year-old is slashing .260/.374/.432 in a bounce-back season, and the impending free agent is making just $2 million on a one-year pact.

ðŸ¤”

Wood will reportedly be called up Monday, and the expectation is that he will see most of his action in left field while Jesse Winker serves as the designated hitter, which would leave Rosario without a path to regular at-bats. Rosario looked like he might be turning a corner in May when he put up an .839 OPS, but his production has fallen off a cliff again in June with a .188/.197/.250 line.

ðŸ¤”

The right-hander appeared to enter 2024 with a chance to see some saves, but Kyle Finnegan has locked down the closer role with the best year of his career. Harvey has labored of late with four walks and four earned runs allowed over his past two outings, but he had a 2.68 ERA through 34 appearances prior to the recent struggles. The 29-year-old will enter his final year of arbitration eligibility in 2025 before hitting free agency.

ðŸ¤”

Floro signed with Washington on a one-year, $2.25 million contract in December, and his 2.15 ERA, 1.06 WHIP and 28:10 K:BB through 39 outings should make him a popular trade target this summer. The 33-year-old tallied 32 saves from 2021 to 2023, but is without a save so far this season and is unlikely to be in the ninth-inning mix if traded.

Corbin's 2.60 ERA across his past three starts could be enough to keep him in Washington's rotation even once Josiah Gray returns from his elbow injury, reports Bobby Blanco of MASNSports.com.

ðŸ¤”

The veteran left-hander seemed to be a sure bet to be jettisoned from Washington's rotation when Gray began his rehab assignment in early June, but Corbin has responded by allowing just five runs with a 16:5 K:BB over 17.1 frames in his past three starts. The 34-year-old's 5.46 ERA is still second worst in the majors among 72 qualified starting pitchers, but the recent improvement could grant him a longer leash in the short term, with the Nationals likely hoping to convert that success into a trade.

ðŸ¤”

Thomas had a .268/.315/.468 slash line with 28 homers and 20 steals last season, but he's hitting just .223 through 38 games in 2024. However, the 28-year-old missed most of May with a knee sprain, and he has an .806 OPS in 16 contests since he returned from the injured list. Thomas is under contract through the 2025 campaign, so it's a natural time for Washington to consider its trade options with a year and a half left under club control. The club will also need to find room in the outfield for top prospects like James Wood, who is currently sidelined by a hamstring injury, and Dylan Crews in the near future.

ðŸ¤”

The right-hander is enjoying a career year in 2024 with 18 saves and a 1.65 ERA, 0.84 WHIP and 29:10 K:BB across 27.1 innings, so it would make sense for Washington to try and sell high given his career 3.33 ERA. Finnegan is making $5.1 million this season in his penultimate year of arbitration eligibility, so it's a logical window to maximize his trade value since he's still under contract for a year and a half.

ðŸ¤”

The veteran outfielder joined Washington as a non-roster invitee in February, and he's enjoyed a rebound campaign with six homers, 11 steals and a .261/.375/.396 slash line in 64 games. Flipping him at the trade deadline appeared to be the best-case scenario for the Nationals when signing him, and Winker has managed to rebuild his trade value after a couple down seasons.

ðŸ¤”

The veteran right-hander landed on the injured list last week, but prior to that he was one of the better stories of the first half of the season. Williams posted a 5.55 ERA in 30 starts for Washington last year, but in 2024 he has a 2.22 ERA, 1.08 WHIP and 47:16 K:BB across 56.2 innings. The 32-year-old is set to become a free agent after the season and could be a strong trade rental for contending teams, assuming he doesn't spend too long on the shelf.

ðŸ¤”

Washington hopes Adams can get back on track offensively at Triple-A, as his .215/.281/.354 slash line through 25 games this season is a sharp drop from his .807 OPS in 2023. Drew Millas is up with the Nationals as the backup catcher to Keibert Ruiz, but Adams could rejoin the big club before long if he can build on his hot start with Rochester, as he went 8-for-17 with three homers in his first four contests.

ðŸ¤”

Opposing batters hit .417 against the right-hander's slider last season, so he tweaked his arsenal during the offseason. Finnegan is throwing the sweeper at the same rate of 5.2 percent, so it's a small sample size of just 13 pitches. The 32-year-old has enjoyed a strong start to the campaign with a 1.65 ERA, 0.86 WHIP and 16:8 K:BB across 16.1 innings, and he's likely to be a popular trade target this summer if the Nationals aren't in playoff contention.

â€Œ

â€Œ

â€Œ

Williams has thrown his four-seam fastball 36.4 percent of the time through seven starts in 2024, which is down from 43.2 percent last season and is the lowest of his big-league career, per Andrew Golden of The Washington Post.

ðŸ¤”

The four-seamer is still his primary offering, but he also has four other pitches that feature rates between 12 and 19 percent. The biggest difference is in his sweeper usage, a pitch Williams introduced in 2023 but threw just 73 times in 30 starts. He's using it at a 17.9 percent clip this season and is giving up a .167 batting average on it. The overall shift in his arsenal was necessary, as the right-hander's average fastball velocity now sits under 90 mph, and the change has brought immediate results with a 1.96 ERA, 1.06 WHIP and 30:12 K:BB over 36.2 frames in 2024.

ðŸ¤”

Rainey spent most of last season rehabbing from Tommy John surgery, and his fastball velocity in 2024 is down more than three ticks from his career average. The right-hander has given up 12 earned runs with an 8:11 K:BB over 12 innings this season and appeared to be in danger of losing his roster spot with Robert Garcia returning from the injured list Tuesday; however, the Nationals aren't yet ready to expose Rainey to waivers, as he is out of minor-league options. The 31-year-old may need to turn a corner soon if he's to retain his place in the bullpen much longer.

ðŸ¤”

No major trades are likely to happen anytime soon, especially for Thomas given the injury, but the outfielder could end up on the block again this summer after the Nationals elected to hold onto him last year. The 28-year-old was off to a poor start prior to the injury with a .184/.250/.253 through 22 games, but he's still likely to be a popular trade candidate this summer, assuming he's healthy, after he posted a .783 OPS last season.

ðŸ¤”

Washington called up infielder Trey Lipscomb in a corresponding move, as the club opted not to bolster their outfield depth. Senzel's only action in the field has come at third base this season, but he primarily played the outfield during his five seasons in Cincinnati.

Ruiz was unavailable Wednesday against the Giants due to an illness, but he should be available Friday versus Oakland since the Nationals demoted No. 3 catcher Drew Millas after Wednesday's contest.

ðŸ¤”

Ruiz started just one of the past three games and will have Thursday's scheduled off day to aid in his recovery from the ailment. The 25-year-old posted a .717 OPS with 18 homers in 136 games last season, but he has a .194/.265/.290 slash line through 34 plate appearances this season.
